facts.text: On June 12, 1961, Vijaysingh the appellant and one Namdeo Shinde drove in a jeep at an excessive speed and dashed it against the wall of the office of the District Superintendent of Police, Akola.

facts.text: High Court allowed State's appeal, dismissed appellant's revision, convicted under s.66(1)(b) with RI 3 months and fine Rs.500, confirmed under s.85(1)(1).

issues.text: Whether, under s.66(2) of the Act, an accused need only prove consumption of a medicinal preparation, upon which the burden shifts to the prosecution to prove that the medicinal preparation is fit for use as an intoxicating liquor?

anchor.surface_text: The first contention may be put thus. Under s. 66 2  of the Act all that an accused need prove is that he has consumed a medical preparation if he established that, the burden of proving that the medicinal preparation is fit for use as an intoxicating liquor shifts to the prosecution.

issues.text: Whether the burden of proof under s.66(2), even if shifted to the accused, is discharged by reason of s.6A deeming the medicinal preparation unfit for intoxicating use until the State Government determines otherwise?

anchor.surface_text: It was then argued that even if the burden of proof in the circumstances of the case shifted to the accused that burden was discharged by reason of s. 6A of the Act. Under s. 6A of the Act for the purpose of enabling the State Government to determine whether any medicinal preparation containing alcohol is an article fit for use as intoxicating liquor,

issues.text: Whether the High Court relied on irrelevant evidence in concluding that the medicinal preparation was fit for use as intoxicating liquor, and specifically, whether the prosecution must prove that consumption has no harmful effects?

anchor.surface_text: The next argument of the learned counsel that the High Court came to the conclusion it did on irrelevant evidence has no force. It is said that the prosecution did not adduce any evidence to prove that Tincture Zingeberis Mitis was not unfit for use as an intoxicating liquor.

issues.text: Whether an offence under s.85(1)(1) requires, in addition to being drunk and incapable of taking care of himself, proof that the accused consumed the intoxicant for the purpose of being intoxicated and not for a medicinal purpose?
What is the question of the construction of some of the provisions of the Bombay Prohibition Act, 1949, raised in this appeal?

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate issued by the High Court of Judicature at Bombay raises the question of the construction of some of the provisions of the Bombay Prohibition Act, 1949, hereinafter called the Act.

arguments.claim: Under s.66(2) of the Act, all that an accused need prove is that he has consumed a medical preparation; if established, the burden of proving that the medicinal preparation is fit for use as an intoxicating liquor shifts to the prosecution. Here, accused established consumption of tincture zingeberis (medicinal), but prosecution failed to prove fitness.

anchor.surface_text: The first contention may be put thus. Under s. 66 2  of the Act all that an accused need prove is that he has consumed a medical preparation if he established that, the burden of proving that the medicinal preparation is fit for use as an intoxicating liquor shifts to the prosecution.

arguments.claim: Even if burden shifted to accused under s.66(2), it is discharged by s.6A deeming medicinal preparation unfit for intoxicating use until State Government determines otherwise; no such determination for Tincture Zingiberis Mitis.

anchor.surface_text: But that decision was given on the relevant provisions of the Act before it was amended by the Bombay Act XII of 1959. Section 66 2  was added by the said Act which in express terms states that in the circumstances mentioned in the sub-section the burden of proof

holdings.text: Under s.66(2) of the Bombay Prohibition Act, once it is proved that the concentration of alcohol in the blood of the accused is not less than 0.05 per cent weight in volume, the burden shifts to the accused to prove that the liquor consumed was a medicinal preparation containing alcohol whose consumption is not in contravention of the Act (i.e., unfit for use as intoxicating liquor under s.24A); in absence of proof, the court presumes the contrary.

anchor.surface_text: Section 66 2  of the Act, which bears on the question of burden of proof, reads thus Subject to the provisions of sub-section  3 , where in any trial of an offence under clause  b  of sub-section  1  for the companysumption of an intoxicant, it is alleged that the accused person companysumed liquor, and it is proved that the companytration of alcohol in the blood of the accused person is number less than 0.05 per cent. weight in volume then the burden of proving that the liquor companysumed was a medicinal or toilet preparation companytaining alcohol, the companysumption of which is number in companytravention of the Act or any rules, regulations or orders made thereunder, shall be upon the accused person, and the Court shall in the absence of such proof presume the companytrary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of s.66(2): burden on accused to prove full exemption including unfitness under s.24A; quoting and applying section to facts where blood alcohol proved >0.05%.

holdings.text: The accused failed to discharge the burden under s.66(2) as he did not prove Tincture Zingiberis Mitis unfit for intoxicating use; prosecution positively established it was fit.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found that the accused had number placed any material to prove that tincture zincreberis mitis was unfit for use as an intoxicating liquor indeed, it accepted the evidence adduced on behalf of the prosecution and held that it was fit for use as an intoxicating liquor. In this case number only the accused fa

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application to facts: accused produced sample but no evidence of unfitness; High Court accepted prosecution evidence (analyser report, experts) showing compliance with specs, high dose for intoxication, consumable without harm.

holdings.text: State of Bombay v. Narandas Mangilal is not applicable after 1959 amendment adding s.66(2), which expressly shifts burden to accused.

anchor.surface_text: But that decision was given on the relevant provisions of the Act before it was amended by the Bombay Act XII of 1959. Section 66 2  was added by the said Act which in express terms states that in the circumstances mentioned in the sub-section the burden of proof

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent distinction: Narandas pre-dates burden-shifting provision; post-amendment law governs.

holdings.text: The High Court correctly concluded on burden of proof and evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The present case falls to be decided on the interpretation of s. 66 2  of the Act. We, therefore, hold that the High Court came to the companyrect companyclusion on the question of burden of proof and gave its finding on the evidence adduced before it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmance: High Court applied correct law and evidence.

holdings.text: s.6A point (deeming unfit until State determination) cannot be entertained as raised first time in Supreme Court without factual record or evidence.

anchor.surface_text: There is companysiderable force in this argument but unfortunately this point was raised only for the first time before us. There is numberhing on the record to show that the State Government has number decided that the said article is fit for use as intoxicating liquor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar: no record of State decision; no material placed even in appeal.

holdings.text: High Court conclusion that Tincture Zingiberis Mitis fit for intoxicating use based on relevant evidence (expert testimony that consumable for intoxication without harmful effects); contention of irrelevant evidence rejected.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the High Court found on the evidence that Tincture Zingeberis Mitis was a preparation which might be companysumed for intoxication and that intoxication would number be accompanied by any harmful effects. This companytention, therefore, must be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence review: prosecution evidence sufficient; no requirement to prove specifically 'no harmful effects' beyond fitness evidence; accused no contrary proof.

holdings.text: Assuming arguendo that s.85(1)(1) requires proof of consumption for intoxication (not medicinal) purpose per s.85(2) presumption, facts show accused consumed for intoxication (rash driving under influence).
